nodes.bodyText: This file seems to exist in /src/test/resources. The other one does not. As far as I can follow, the physical file is not needed by the test, since repository is mocked? If so, it would be good to remove the file.
File removed from resources.

Since we're mocking readBackupFile anyhow, there is probably no real need for actual physical file src/test/resources/ss-automatic-backup-2020_02_19_031502.tar?
Same test coverage result can be achieved by byte[] bytes = "foobar".getBytes(StandardCharsets.UTF_8); and this way test could be more self-contained and we could avoid storing a backup file in version control, which has a small but positive result in simplifying things.
File removed and updated test as suggested.
Other converters use singular form for naming, e.g. ClientConverter -> BackupConverter

nodes.bodyText:
Moved converter reference from service layer to API layer. In addition, I added a new BackupFile DTO that is used by the service layer.
50b21f4#diff-4a6737d3ff19bbbfdb8b6edc282a5df2

I am not sure if ACCEPTED is the correct one here?

status code indicates that the request has been received but not yet acted upon

backupsService.generateBackup is synchronous, at this point backup has been created. Should we be using regular CREATED instead (with the ApiUtil-added details)?

Return code is changed to CREATED. However, I did not use ApiUtil-added details since we don't have an endpoint to access the metadata of a specific backup. This is aligned with other similar endpoints, e.g. adding a configured timestamping service (POST /api/timestamping-services).

In the case of BackupFileNotFoundException, is GENERATE_BACKUP_INTERRUPTED not potentially misleading error code? Maybe just new InternalServerErrorException(e) in that case?
But, I think I will add another comment about use of BackupFileNotFoundException to service, it might not be needed at all.

I like writing out definitions, in which situations certain checked exceptions can be thrown. I think it's good because

it documents this to the clients who call this method (well, duh)
it is a good though exercise. Writing the descriptions forces one to think through about the different exception situations, and often reveals that certain exceptions should be replaced, or not thrown as checked exceptions at all
Javadoc is not up to date, ProcessNotExecutableException and ProcessFailedException are not thrown, and BackupFileNotFoundException is missing

Deciding which cases to identify as checked exceptions is important, but tricky and challenging job. And usually ends up being somewhat subjective. I wrote about the topic in https://confluence.niis.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=30212590
In this method we have ProcessNotExecutableException, ProcessFailedException and BackupFileNotFoundException. Question is which ones should be checked exceptions, which not.
ProcessNotExecutableException and ProcessFailedException are wrapped as DeviationAwareRuntimeExceptions. Logic is probably "these mean that something in internal engine is broken, and method's caller is not interested in what. http 500 is enough".
I am maybe a bit dubious about ProcessFailedException, it might make sense to throw it as checked exception....but since that is from generateInternalTlsKeyAndCertificate and other places, lets leave it as it is.
But I would consider wrapping the BackupFileNotFoundException also in an unchecked DeviationAwareRuntimeException? If backup script completed, and still we dont find the backup, isn't that just as much "something in the internals is broken, and all we want to do is http 500" case as "process is not executable"?

Should we implement the same logic? I think this implementation would list more backups than the old UI (e.g. backup files starting with a dot)

The new UI/API implements now the same validation rules that the old UI does. Subdirectories are excluded using DIR_MAX_DEPTH = 1 and valid file names are limited to "^(?!\\.)[\\w\\.\\-]+\\.tar$" pattern.

Very nice! Documenting what the regexp does in

 is also really great, since regexps are difficult to read and adding a few lines of comments helps reviewer / modifier a lot.
Using OffsetDateTime here would not be wrong choice either, since that is what we will end up using after some conversions, anyway.
I changed it OffsetDateTime which made the implementation more straightforward.

I guess there would be also this option https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/attribute/BasicFileAttributes.html which removes the need for attribute name String https://stackoverflow.com/a/2724009/1469083
Not very important detail though.
Changed.

Usually generic advice is that these should use File.separator instead of "/". There is some limited use of File.separator in the codebase already.
DefaultFilepaths.CONF_BACKUP_PATH uses hard coded "/" but maybe there is some tiny change that someone will run this with overridden CONF_BACKUP_PATH on a system with different file separator.
I don't see how File.separator would break otherwise working configuration, so there should not be too much of a downside for changing. But this is not a super important detail. It's more of a style issue.

You're right, the default configuration includes the trailing /. Since the default value can be overridden, it's possible for an admin to change the location and set the new value without the trailing /. Maybe not very common, but possible. However, I replaced the hardcoded / with File.separator.
maybe more idiomatic naming is that a backupExists() method returns boolean, and method returning Optional is named e.g. getBackup()
Method name updated.

How does this work with weird / hostile filenames? Could you use e.g. path travelsals ("../../etc/passwd")?
Spring firewall prevents some of these on the controller layer currently, but service should be safe anyway.

Before trying to read the file, the given filename is validated against existing backup files. If the given filename does not match to an existing backup filename, BackupFileNotFoundException exception is thrown. The existing backup file names must meet the requirements of the backup filename filter.
https://github.com/nordic-institute/X-Road/pull/385/files#diff-de66d07ae90cf7c796f633208bd7dc09R55
This should prevent access to other than valid backup files.
Good, I did not fully track how readBackupFile is used - seems exploits are not possible. Also, the added more strict filename validation helps in this.
